documents.title: Order Granting in Part and Denying in Part Plaintiffs' Motion to Allow Parents Deported Without Their Children to Travel to the United States
documents.text:
Case 3:18-cv-00428-DMS-MDD   Document 456   Filed 09/04/19   PageID.7776   Page 1 of 21
 
1   
2   
3   
4   
5   
6   
7   
8  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
9  SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
10   
11  Ms. L.; et al.,    Case No.:  18cv0428 DMS (MDD) 
 
12  Petitioners-Plaintiffs, 
ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND 
13  v.  DENYING IN PART PLAINTIFFS’ 
MOTION TO ALLOW PARENTS 
14  U.S. Immigration and Customs 
DEPORTED WITHOUT THEIR 
Enforcement (“ICE”); et al., 
15  CHILDREN TO TRAVEL TO THE 
Respondents-Defendants.  UNITED STATES 
16 
 
17 
  Plaintiffs bring the present motion to allow a small group of migrant parents who 
18 
were separated from their minor children at the border, and then deported without their 
19 
children, to travel to the United States so they may be reunited with their children and 
20 
pursue their asylum claims as provided by law.  These parents are members of the Ms. L. 
21 
Class, which was certified by this Court on June 26, 2018.  That Class included over 2,800 
22 
parents who were forcibly separated from their children at the United States-Mexico border 
23 
under the Administration’s immigration policies.  (See 8/14/19 Joint Status Report, ECF 
24 
No. 444.)1  Thereafter, the children were detained in government-run facilities throughout 
25 
26 
                                                
27 
1  On March 8, 2019, the Court modified the class definition to include parents who entered 
28 
the United States with their children beginning on July 1, 2017.  (See ECF No. 386.)  
1 
18cv0428 DMS (MDD) 

Case 3:18-cv-00428-DMS-MDD   Document 456   Filed 09/04/19   PageID.7777   Page 2 of 21
 
1  the United States.  Pursuant to this Court’s orders, all of these children have now been 
2  accounted for and more than 2,300 of them have been reunified with at least one of their 
3  parents.  But during the chaotic and unprecedented practice of separating these migrant 
4  families, 471 of the parents were deported without their children.  (ECF No. 382 at 7.)2  All 
5  of these parents have now been found through the herculean efforts of the parties.3  Many 
6  of the parents were located in remote villages in the recesses of Central America, and nearly 
7  all of them have now made the difficult decision either to reunify with their children in 
8  their home countries or to waive reunification and allow their children to remain in the 
9  United States to pursue their own claims for asylum in accordance with established law.   
10  Thirty of the 471 parents returned to the United States without permission and sought 
11  asylum upon apprehension.  According to Plaintiffs, all thirty of these parents either passed 
12  a credible fear interview or were placed directly into immigration proceedings before an 
13  immigration judge, and were subsequently reunified with their children.  Eighteen other 
14  parents,4 who are the subject of the present motion, are also seeking to return to the United 
15 
                                                
16 
17  Defendants, led admirably by Commander Jonathan White of the Department of Health 
and Human Services, are currently working to identify how many children of these parents 
18 
went through government custody, and how many additional parents will be included in 
19  the Class.  These additional numbers are not included in the approximately 2,800 parents 
referenced here.       
20 
2  Defendants have identified 471 parents “who were removed from the United States 
21  without  their  children,  and  without  being  given  the  opportunity  to  elect  or  waive 
reunification in accordance with the [June 26, 2018] preliminary injunction.”  (Id.)  The 
22 
enlarged class of Ms. L. parents, as defined in the Court’s March 8, 2019 Order, may 
23  include many more parents who were removed without their children.  See n.1, supra.   
3    Plaintiffs  established  a  steering  committee  comprised  of  volunteers  and  non-
24 
governmental organizations (“NGOs”).  Mr. Steven Herzog and his law firm, Paul, Weiss, 
25  Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, devoted hundreds of hours of pro bono legal services.  NGOs 
such as Justice in Motion and Kids in Need of Defense (“KIND”) also devoted countless 
26 
hours toward the important and unprecedented effort of locating parents in Central America 
27  who had been separated from their minor children. 
4  Plaintiffs originally sought relief on behalf of twenty-one parents but have now limited 
28 
the request to eighteen parents.  See, infra, at 9-10.   
2 
18cv0428 DMS (MDD) 

Case 3:18-cv-00428-DMS-MDD   Document 456   Filed 09/04/19   PageID.7778   Page 3 of 21
 
1  States, but rather than doing so unilaterally, they are requesting that the Court order the 
2  Government to allow them to return so they, too, may be reunited with their children and 
3  pursue their asylum claims under existing law and procedures. 
4  Plaintiffs argue they are entitled to this relief under a Settlement Agreement entered 
5  into between the parties in this case, as well as under Ninth Circuit law that provides for 
6  the return of an alien who is wrongfully removed.  Defendants oppose the motion.  The 
7  matter has been fully briefed and argued.  For the reasons discussed below, the Court finds 
8  eleven of the parents are entitled to the relief requested under Ninth Circuit law and seven 
9  are not, those parents having failed to meet their burden of proving they were wrongfully 
10  removed.   
11  I. 
12  DISCUSSION 
13    On June 26, 2018, this Court certified the Ms. L. Class of parents and generally 
14  included in the Class those parents who were (1) separated from their minor children at the 
15  border pursuant to the Administration’s immigration policies and (2) did not have criminal 
16  history (with limited exceptions), were not unfit and did not present a danger to their 
17  children.  The Court also issued on the same day a preliminary injunction prohibiting 
18  Defendants from further separating parents and their children at the border as there was a 
19  likelihood that conduct violated the parents’ Fifth Amendment due process rights to family 
20  integrity under the United States Constitution.  The preliminary injunction also ordered 
21  Defendants to reunite the families that had already been separated.  There is no dispute the 
22  eighteen parents at issue fall within the Ms. L. Class.   
23  The circumstances of the eighteen parents’ immigration and removal proceedings 
24  vary widely.  Twelve of the eighteen parents were removed before this Court issued its 
25  class certification order and preliminary injunction.  Two other parents were removed after 
26  those orders issued, but before this Court issued a stay of any further removals.  Three 
27  parents were removed after the stay, and it is unclear when the remaining parent was 
28  removed.   
3 
18cv0428 DMS (MDD) 

Case 3:18-cv-00428-DMS-MDD   Document 456   Filed 09/04/19   PageID.7779   Page 4 of 21
 
1  Of the twelve parents  who were removed before issuance of the Court’s class 
2  certification order and preliminary injunction, two subsequently returned to the United 
3  States illegally, and were again removed without their children.  It appears these two 
4  parents fell outside the scope of the court-approved Settlement Agreement in this case, (see 
5  ECF No. 321), and thus were subject to removal, because they were not “continuously 
6  physically present in the United States since June 26, 2018[.]”  (ECF No. 220-1 at 1.5)   
7  Sixteen of the eighteen parents entered the United States illegally at the southern 
8  border with Mexico, while two of the parents entered legally through designated ports of 
9  entry.  And although the majority of those entering illegally were transferred to criminal 
10  custody and prosecuted under the Administration’s “zero tolerance policy”6 before being 
11  returned to immigration custody, it appears others were not charged with a crime and were 
12  detained only in immigration custody. 
13    Waiver forms executed by the parents, purporting to waive the parents’ rights to be 
14  reunified with their children prior to removal, also varied.  One parent signed the court-
15  approved form that was supposed to be attached to the Class Notice.  Others signed a form 
16  provided by Defendants prior to the Court’s approval of the Class Notice.  And still others 
17  signed forms of unknown origin. 
18    Finally, the length of each parent’s separation from their child varied considerably.  
19  One parent was separated from his child for nine days, while another parent was separated 
20  from her child for nearly seven months.  And although each parent suffered the same injury,  
21 
22 
                                                
23 
5  The page numbers cited here and throughout this Order correspond to the page numbers 
24 
assigned by the Court’s CM/ECF filing system. 
25  6  On May 7, 2018, the Attorney General of the United States announced a zero tolerance 
policy, in which all adults entering the country illegally would be criminally prosecuted.  
26 
In accordance with that policy, parents who crossed between ports of entry with their minor 
27  children were separated from their children and prosecuted.  Many of those parents were 
returned to immigration custody after serving their criminal sentence and then deported 
28 
without their children. 
4 
18cv0428 DMS (MDD) 

Case 3:18-cv-00428-DMS-MDD   Document 456   Filed 09/04/19   PageID.7780   Page 5 of 21
 
1  namely separation from their child, the effect of that injury on each parent and their 
2  respective immigration case was different.    
3    Despite these varying circumstances, Plaintiffs move the Court to allow all eighteen 
4  parents to return to the United States as a group.  Plaintiffs are not asking the Court to order 
5  Defendants to pay for or otherwise arrange travel for these parents to the United States.  
6  (ECF  No. 434  at 49-50.)    Rather, they  are  moving  the  Court  for  an order directing 
7  Defendants to allow the parents to return to the United States so they can be reunified with 
8  their children and proceed with their asylum claims.  (Id. at 50.)  As noted, Plaintiffs argue 
9  the Court has authority to grant this relief pursuant to either the court-approved Settlement 
10  Agreement  in  this  case  or  the  Court’s  inherent  authority  under  Ninth  Circuit  law.  
11  Defendants dispute that the Settlement Agreement gives the Court authority to grant the 
12  requested relief.  Indeed, they argue the Settlement Agreement forecloses the Court’s 
13  ability to do so.  Aside from the Settlement Agreement, Defendants also assert the Court 
14  lacks jurisdiction to order the relief requested here.  Each argument is addressed in turn. 
15  A.  Settlement Agreement 
16  The entirety of the relevant provision of the Settlement Agreement is found under 
17  the heading, “The return of removed parents to the United States.”   It provides:   
18  The government does not intend to, nor does it agree to, return any removed 
parent to the United States or to facilitate any return of such removed parents.  
19 
The classes agree not to pursue any right or claim of removed parents to return 
20  to the United States other than as specifically set forth in this paragraph.  
Plaintiffs’ counsel may raise with the government individual cases in which 
21 
plaintiffs’ counsel believes the return of a particular removed Ms. L class 
22  member may be warranted.  Plaintiffs’ counsel represent that they believe that 
such individual cases will be rare and unusual and that they have no basis for 
23 
believing that such individual cases will be other than rare and unusual.  
24  Plaintiffs’ counsel agree to present any such cases, including all evidence they 
would like considered by the government within 30 days of the approval of 
25 
this agreement.  In light of plaintiffs’ counsel’s representation that such cases 
26  will be rare and unusual, Defendants agree to provide a reply to any case 
presented  by  Plaintiffs  within  30  days  of  receiving  Plaintiffs’  request  to 
27 
consider the case.  Except as specifically set forth herein, the classes agree 
28 
5 
18cv0428 DMS (MDD) 

Case 3:18-cv-00428-DMS-MDD   Document 456   Filed 09/04/19   PageID.7781   Page 6 of 21
 
1  that existing law, existing procedures, and the Court-approved reunification 
plan address all interests that such parents or their children may have.   
2 
3  (ECF No. 315-2 at 7.)7  There is no dispute this provision sets out a procedure for the parties 
4  to follow in the event Plaintiffs believe that return to the United States is warranted for an 
5  individual Ms. L. class member.  Under that procedure, Plaintiffs agree to present any cases 
6  warranting return to Defendants, and Defendants agree to provide a response within thirty 
7  days of receiving Plaintiffs’ request.  Other than these two requirements, however, the 
8  Agreement fails to set out any specifics.  For instance, while the Agreement reflects 
9  Plaintiffs’ belief that such cases will be “rare and unusual,” it does not set out the criteria 
10  by which Plaintiffs will decide that return to the United States is warranted.  Nor does the 
11  Agreement  set  out  the  criteria  by  which  Defendants  will  review  Plaintiffs’  requests.  
12  Defendants argue that return to the United States would be warranted only in “rare and 
13  unusual”  cases,  whatever  that  might  mean.    But  the  Court reads  that  portion  of  the 
14  Agreement simply to reflect a good faith standard: Plaintiffs’ belief that individual cases 
15  warranting return will be “rare and unusual,” not that only “rare and unusual” cases will 
16  warrant return.   
17    On its face, the Agreement does little more than outline procedures the parties will 
18  follow in the event Plaintiffs’ counsel believe “the return of a particular removed Ms. L 
19  class member may be warranted.”  (Id.)  Both parties have complied with these general 
20  procedures.  But the Agreement does not provide for any further relief if Plaintiffs’ requests 
21  for return are rejected.  Thus, Plaintiffs’ motion to the extent it relies on the Settlement 
22  Agreement is denied. 
23    Defendants argue the only relief available to Plaintiffs is under the Settlement 
24  Agreement, and that relief does not include the return of these parents once Defendants 
25 
                                                
26 
27  7  The Settlement Agreement was filed in both this case and in a related class action case 
involving the minor children of the Ms. L. class members.  See M.M.M. v. Jefferson 
28 
Sessions, et. al., Case No. 18cv1832 DMS (MDD).   
6 
18cv0428 DMS (MDD) 

Case 3:18-cv-00428-DMS-MDD   Document 456   Filed 09/04/19   PageID.7782   Page 7 of 21
 
1  have  evaluated  and  rejected  Plaintiffs’  requests.    In  support,  Defendants  rely  on  the 
2  language of the Settlement Agreement that states “[t]he classes agree not to pursue any 
3  right or claim of removed parents to return to the United States other than as specifically 
4  set forth in this paragraph.”  (ECF No. 315-2 at 7.)  However, the Agreement also provides 
5  that “the classes agree that existing law, existing procedures, and the Court-approved 
6  reunification plan address all interests that such parents or their children may have.”  (Id.)  
7  Plaintiffs are pursuing relief under existing law.  The Court, therefore, declines to find that 
8  the Settlement Agreement provides the only basis for the relief requested in the present 
9  motion.   
10  B.  Ninth Circuit Law 
11  As an alternative to the Settlement Agreement, Plaintiffs argue the Court may grant 
12  the requested relief pursuant to its “remedial authority to effectuate its injunction and 
13  ensure a meaningful opportunity for reunification.”  (Mem. of P. & A. in Supp. of Mot. at 
14  11.)  In support, Plaintiffs rely on a series of Ninth Circuit cases involving the court-ordered 
15  return of aliens who were wrongfully deported.  See Walters v. Reno, 145 F.3d 1032 (9th 
16  Cir. 1998); Singh v. Waters, 87 F.3d 346 (9th Cir. 1996); Mendez v. Immigration and 
17  Naturalization Service, 563 F.2d 956 (9th Cir. 1977).  Defendants do not address these 
18  cases, relying instead on the argument that the Court lacks jurisdiction to order Defendants 
19  to allow the return of these parents.  (See Opp’n to Mot. at 17-19.)  Defendants cite a 
20  number of cases that speak to the power of the legislative and executive branches of the 
21  federal government “over the subject of immigration and the status of aliens.”  Arizona v. 
22  United States, 567 U.S. 387, 394 (2012).  But none of the cases cited by Defendants 
23  addresses the specific issue raised here, which is whether the Court may order Defendants 
24  to allow parents who were separated from their children at the border pursuant to a 
25  nationwide policy, and who were subsequently deported without their children, to travel 
26  back to the United States so they may be reunified with their children and have a renewed 
27  opportunity to request asylum free from the trauma of that separation.  Indeed, given the 
28  unprecedented nature of this situation, there are no cases directly on point.   
7 
18cv0428 DMS (MDD) 

Case 3:18-cv-00428-DMS-MDD   Document 456   Filed 09/04/19   PageID.7783   Page 8 of 21
 
1  However, the Ninth Circuit cases cited by Plaintiffs are instructive.  See Walters, 
2  145 F.3d 1036 (reviewing permanent injunction requiring INS to parole class members into 
3  the United States as a result of due process violations during immigration proceedings); 
4  Singh, 87 F.3d at 346-50 (reviewing denial of habeas petition filed by deported alien 
5  alleging  unlawful  deportation);  Mendez,  563  F.2d  at  957-59  (reviewing  challenge  of 
6  deported  alien  to  deportation  order  where  alien  was  deprived  of  right  to  counsel  in 
7  immigration proceeding).  In each of the foregoing cases, the court rejected the defendant’s 
8  argument that the court lacked authority to order return of the alien to the United States.  
9  See Walters, 145 F.3d at 1050-51 (rejecting argument “that the district court exceeded its 
10  authority in requiring the INS to grant parole to these individuals, as a matter of both recent 
11  statutory developments and of circuit precedent.”); Singh, 87 F.3d at 347 (holding district 
12  court had jurisdiction over habeas petition seeking petitioner’s return to the United States); 
13  Mendez, 563 F.2d at 958-59 (rejecting jurisdictional challenge to appeal of immigration 
14  orders).  In light of these cases, the Court rejects Defendants’ jurisdictional argument and 
15  finds it has authority to grant the requested relief if a parent was wrongfully deported.   
16  The circumstances of each parent’s case must therefore be examined, and Plaintiffs 
17  carry the burden of proving that each parent was unlawfully or improperly removed.8  
18  Plaintiffs, however, argue the group as a whole should be allowed to return to the United 
19  States because they meet three criteria:  (1) they present bona fide claims for asylum, (2) 
20  their asylum claims were abandoned or lost due to coercion or trauma inflicted by the 
21  family separation policy, and (3) they are unable to reunify in their home country because 
22  of fear of harm to themselves and their children.  (Mem. in Supp. of Mot. at 7-8.)  There is 
23  no legal authority establishing these criteria as a basis for the relief sought.  Rather, Ninth 
24  Circuit case law provides that the relief sought here, primarily, the parents’ return to the 
25  United States, depends on a finding that the parents were unlawfully deported.  See Walters, 
26 
                                                
27 
8  During the August 16, 2019 status conference, Plaintiffs’ counsel conceded that Plaintiffs 
28 
bear the burden to show that any removals were unlawful.  (ECF No. 452 at 28.) 
8 
18cv0428 DMS (MDD) 

Case 3:18-cv-00428-DMS-MDD   Document 456   Filed 09/04/19   PageID.7784   Page 9 of 21
 
1  145 F.3d at 1050-51 (upholding parole into United States as remedy for due process 
2  violation in immigration proceedings); Singh, 87 F.3d at 347 (holding petitioner’s unlawful 
3  deportation entitled him to habeas relief, including return to the United States); Mendez, 
4  563 F.2d at 958 (stating issue was whether the “departure was ‘legally executed’ [] when 
5  effected by the government.”) 
6    Plaintiffs initially argued the parents’ deportations were illegal based on “the trauma 
7  of family separation, in conjunction with statutory and regulatory violations[.]”  (Pls.’ 
8  Supp. Br. in Supp. of Mot. at 3.)  During a subsequent status conference,  however, 
9  Plaintiffs made clear their lead argument was that the deportations of these parents were 
10  unlawful based solely on their separation from their children.  (ECF No. 452 at 28-29.)  As 
11  traumatic and unlawful as the separations may have been, the Court declines to find that 
12  separation of the family—standing alone—renders the subsequent removal of the parent 
13  unlawful.  Rather, to be entitled to the relief sought here, the circumstances surrounding 
14  the separation of each parent from his or her child must have caused the deportation or 
15  removal to be unlawful, e.g., the separation must have affected the voluntariness of the 
16  parent’s decisions in the immigration proceedings, or there must have been a statutory or 
17  regulatory violation in the immigration process independent of the separation, e.g., a failure 
18  to provide a credible fear interview in the face of a credible fear claim.  This inquiry must 
19  be addressed on an individual basis, not to the group as a whole.  See Walters, 145 F.3d at 
20  1051 (discussing individual nature of parole decision).   
21    Since  the  parties  did  not  frame  the  issue  in  these  individual  terms,  the  Court 
22  requested supplemental briefing from the parties and ordered Defendants to produce the 
23  parents’ immigration records to fully develop the facts of each parent’s case.  (See ECF 
24  No. 437.)9  In the course of the supplemental briefing, Defendants agreed to return one of 
25 
26 
                                                
27 
9  Defendants produced approximately 245 pages relating to the immigration proceedings 
28 
of the eighteen parents.  Although Defendants also had an opportunity to submit their own 
9 
18cv0428 DMS (MDD) 

Case 3:18-cv-00428-DMS-MDD   Document 456   Filed 09/04/19   PageID.7785   Page 10 of 21
 
1  the twenty-one original parents to the United States because he was removed without first 
2  receiving a credible fear interview in violation of law.  It also appears another parent is 
3  already in the United States with “pending INA § 240 proceedings” before an immigration 
4  judge.  In addition, Plaintiffs indicated they would not be pursuing relief as to another one 
5  of the twenty-one original parents, leaving only the eighteen parents at issue.  The Court 
6  has now reviewed the records of each parent and makes the following findings. 
7  C.  Findings 
8    A.D.G. – The records reflect A.D.G. and his daughter were apprehended by Border 
9  Patrol agents on May 30, 2018, near Hidalgo, Texas.  (ECF No. 448 at 6.)  A.D.G.’s Form 
10  I-21310 includes a notation that A.D.G. was part of a family unit.  (Id. at 5.)  It also includes 
11  a statement that A.D.G. did not fear being returned to his country of origin.  (Id. at 8.)  In 
12  A.D.G.’s Declaration submitted in support of this motion, he states, “I told officials on 
13  several occasions that I was afraid to return to [my country of origin].”  (ECF No. 430 at 
14  4.)  It is unclear, however, whether those claims were made to an immigration officer, as 
15  required.  The relevant statute provides that if an alien indicates to an “immigration officer” 
16  either an intention to apply for asylum or a fear of persecution, that officer shall refer the 
17  alien for an interview by an asylum officer.  See 8 U.S.C. § 1225(b)(1)(A)(ii).11  Based on 
18  the evidence submitted and other court records, it appears A.D.G. was at some point 
19  transferred to criminal custody, and it appears his claims may have been made to a federal 
20 
                                                
21 
declarations in response to the parents’ declarations, they did not do so.  Thus, the findings 
22 
herein are based on the parents’ declarations and the documents produced by the parties.   
23  10  Plaintiffs state the Form I-213 “is the form that Customs and Border Patrol agents 
complete soon after initially apprehending an individual.”  (Pls.’ Supp. Br. in Supp. of Mot. 
24 
at 4 n.3.)   
25  11  The statute provides: “If an immigration officer determines that an alien (other than an 
alien described in subparagraph (F)) who is arriving in the United States or is described in 
26 
clause (iii) is inadmissible under section 1182(a)(6)(C) or 1182(a)(7) of this title and the 
27  alien indicates either an intention to apply for asylum under section 1158 of this title or a 
fear of persecution, the officer shall refer the alien for an interview by an asylum officer 
28 
under subparagraph (B).”  8 U.S.C. § 1225(b)(1)(A)(ii).   
10 
18cv0428 DMS (MDD) 

Case 3:18-cv-00428-DMS-MDD   Document 456   Filed 09/04/19   PageID.7786   Page 11 of 21
 
1  correctional officer rather than an immigration officer.  In light of the evidence, it is unclear

3  Furthermore, although A.D.G. attests to the emotional distress he suffered as a result of

5  deportation proceedings.  Based on the present record, Plaintiffs have not met their burden

7    B.L.S.P. – The evidence reflects B.L.S.P. and her son were apprehended by Border 
8  Patrol agents on November 20, 2017, in Presidio, Texas.  (ECF No. 448 at 19.)  Although 
9  B.L.S.P.’s Form I-213 states she did not fear persecution or harm should she be returned 
10  to her country of origin, (id. at 19-20) (B.L.S.P. “stated she does  not fear persecution or 
11  harm should she be returned to native country ….”), she in fact was later provided a 
12  credible fear interview.  (ECF No. 430 at 10.)  It is unclear exactly how long B.L.S.P. was 
13  separated from her son before her credible fear interview, but it may have been anywhere 
14  from one to four months.  During that time, B.L.S.P. “was constantly crying.”  (Id. at 9.)   
15  For a month, B.L.S.P. had no information about where her son was, and she 
felt that she could faint from the pain she was feeling. …  B.L.S.P. was so 
16 
stressed by the separation from her son that part of her face became paralyzed 
17  for 2-3 days.  It was extremely swollen and very painful.  …  B.L.S.P. felt 
powerless, overwhelmed by depression from the abrupt separation from her 
18 
son, all her past traumas resurfaced, and she had difficulties getting through 
19  the days.   
20  (Id.  at  9-10.)    B.L.S.P.  passed  her  credible  fear  interview  and  was  referred  to  an 
21  immigration judge (“IJ”).  (Id. at 10.)  Two months passed, however, before B.L.S.P.’s 
22  hearing before the IJ.  (Id.)  By that point, B.L.S.P. had been separated from her son for 
23  nearly six months.  During the hearing, the IJ told B.L.S.P. that it would be another five 
24  months before her asylum hearing would be scheduled.  (Id. at 11.)   
25  B.L.S.P. was overwhelmed and traumatized by the ongoing and indefinite 
separation from her child.  Faced with potentially almost a year before her 
26 
asylum claim could be heard and the prospect of ongoing separation from her 
27  child throughout this time, she felt defeated, hopeless and unable to remain 
separated nor to focus on her asylum claim.  …  B.L.S.P. was so distraught at 
28 
the idea of being separated from her child for what would be closer to a year

Case 3:18-cv-00428-DMS-MDD   Document 456   Filed 09/04/19   PageID.7787   Page 12 of 21
 
1  by the time her next hearing was scheduled that she decided she could not take 
the suffering anymore and she withdrew her application and asked to go back 
2 
to [her country of origin].   
3   
4  (Id.) 
5    In B.L.S.P.’s case, the issue for the Court is whether her decision to withdraw her 
6  application for asylum and withholding of removal was voluntary.  See 8 C.F.R. § 235.4 
7  (stating alien’s “decision to withdraw his or her application for admission must be made 
8  voluntarily[.]”)12    The  evidence  presented  clearly  warrants  a  finding  that  B.L.S.P.’s 
9  withdrawal  of  her  claims  was  not  voluntary.    When  B.L.S.P.  and  her  son  entered 
10  immigration detention on November 20, 2017, they were separated, and the following day 
11  B.L.S.P. awoke and found “her son was gone.”  (ECF No. 430 at 9.)  She remained 
12  separated from her son for several months, and for a month, “had no information about 
13  where her son was[.]”  (Id.)  She was thereafter allowed only limited phone contact with 
14  her son, and during the time they were separated, she suffered not only emotional harm, 
15  but physical harm as well.  (Id. at 9-10.)  After nearly six months of separation, and being 
16  told that she would remain separated from her son for another five months, “[s]he chose to 
17  abandon her claim rather than continue the punishment of separation from her child.”  (Id. 
18  at 11.)  The Court cannot say B.L.S.P.’s decision to withdraw her applications was the 
19  product of a free and deliberate choice, particularly when she made her decision as a result 
20  of the continued separation from her child.  B.L.S.P.’s subsequent removal based on the 
21  alleged voluntary withdrawal of her claim was therefore unlawful.

1    C.A.C. – The circumstances surrounding C.A.C.’s removal raise yet other issues.  
2  Specifically, C.A.C. executed the court-approved Form that was supposed to be provided 
3  to class members along with the Class Notice.  C.A.C. chose the following option:  “If I 
4  lose my [immigration] case and am going to be removed, I do NOT want to take my child 
5  with me.”  (ECF No. 448 at 29.)  That Form was approved by the Court on July 10, 2018.  
6  (See ECF No. 103.)  It appears C.A.C. signed the Form on July 13, 2018.  (ECF No. 448 
7  at 29.)  He was then removed on July 20, 2018.  (Id. at 22.)   
8  The problem with C.A.C.’s removal is that on July 16, 2018, this Court granted 
9  Plaintiffs’ motion to stay the removal of class members pending full briefing on that issue.  
10  (ECF No. 117 at 4.)  It appears that C.A.C.’s removal was in violation of that Order, and 
11  therefore unlawful.  See Singh, 87 F.3d at 349 (finding removal unlawful where alien was 
12  deported after stay of deportation had been issued by immigration judge).   
13  Two other parents appear to have suffered a similar fate: E.A.S.M. and E.F.A.R.  
14  These parents appear to have been removed in violation of the Court’s stay order.  (See 
15  ECF No. 448 at 101, 124) (indicating removal of E.A.S.M. on July 16, 2018, and removal 
16  of E.F.A.R. on August 22, 2018).  Indeed, E.F.A.R. was removed not only after the Court’s 
17  stay order, but after the Court issued a temporary restraining order prohibiting Defendants 
18  from removing Class Members.  Accordingly, the removals of these two additional parents 
19  were also unlawful.

21  dispute whether he made a credible fear claim.  C.P.E. claims he did, (see ECF No. 430 at 
22  19) (“I told the officials that I was afraid to go back to [my country of origin], but they 
23  ignored me.”), but his Form I-213 reflects he did not.  (ECF No. 448 at 34) (“the subject 
24  does not [ ] claim fear persecution or torture if returned to the subject’s country of

26  credible fear claim.  Plaintiffs have not met their burden to show C.P.E.’s removal was 
27  unlawful.

1  D.C.C. – D.C.C. presents circumstances similar to those of A.D.G. and C.P.E. in 
2  that there is a dispute about whether he made a credible fear claim.  Unlike A.D.G. and 
3  C.P.E., D.C.C. appears to  allege he  made a credible fear  claim during his screening 
4  interview with an immigration officer.  (See ECF No. 430 at 24, ¶ 6.)  Defendants submit 
5  a Form I-213, which refutes D.C.C.’s assertions and states, “Subject made a statement 
6  claiming no fear of being returned to his country of origin.”  (ECF No. 448 at 41.)  But 
7  there is more to D.C.C.’s case.  D.C.C. provides evidence he was subject to coercion and 
8  misrepresentations by the immigration officer.  (ECF No. 430 at 24.)  For instance, D.C.C. 
9  states the immigration officer told him his “papers were already completed” and that he 
10  “had to return” to his country of origin.  (Id.)  The officer said he “had to sign the paper, 
11  that there was no choice.”  (Id.)  He stated that if D.C.C. “didn’t sign the papers, he would 
12  sign for me, so I signed.”  (Id.)  The officer also said in response to D.C.C.’s claim of fear 
13  that D.C.C. “was not allowed to stay in the United States because the President had changed 
14  the law and only [D.C.C.’s] son could stay.”  (Id.)  These circumstances sufficiently 
15  demonstrate D.C.C.’s removal was based on an involuntary waiver of his rights as a result 
16  of the officer’s actions.  Plaintiffs have therefore met their burden to show D.C.C.’s 
17  removal was unlawful.  
18  D.J.M. – D.J.M.’s case also presents a dispute about whether he made a credible 
19  fear claim.  In his Declaration, D.J.M. states “[t]he agents did not ask me if I was afraid to 
20  return to [my country of origin].”  (ECF No. 430 at 31.)  D.J.M. states, “I tried to explain 
21  that  I  could  not go back to  [my  country  of origin]  but it  was difficult  without [an] 
22  interpreter.”  (Id.)  While D.J.M. states he had difficulty communicating, he does not state 
23  he was unable to do so.  And D.J.M’s Form I-213 states he “claimed no fear of persecution 
24  or torture if he is returned to his native country ….”  (ECF No. 446 at 45-46.)  As with the 
25  others discussed above, Plaintiffs have not met their burden to show D.J.M.’s removal was 
26  unlawful.

1  as to this exchange, but appears to confirm that D.X.C. was separated from his son.  (ECF 
2  No. 448 at 97.)  As for credible fear, the Form states, “the subject does not [ ] claim fear 
3  persecution or torture if returned to the subject’s country of citizenship.”  (Id.) 
4  As stated, 8 C.F.R. § 235.4 states that an alien’s “decision to withdraw his or her 
5  application for admission must be made voluntarily[.]”  D.X.C.’s Declaration reflects he 
6  did not voluntarily withdraw his claim.  Rather, it reflects the immigration officials coerced 
7  him to drop his asylum claim.  See Orantes-Hernandez v. Smith, 541 F. Supp. 351, 372-74 
8  (C.D. Cal. 1982) (discussing “coercive tactics to cause members of the class to accept 
9  ‘voluntary departure’ to El Salvador”); see also United States v. Tingle, 658 F.2d 1332, 
10  1336 (9th Cir. 1981) (finding officers’ warning to parent, including that parent “might not 
11  see … two-year-old child for a while … patently coercive.”)  Specifically, after the initial 
12  officer was unable to persuade D.X.C. to sign the document, another officer was brought 
13  into the interview room.  The second officer then threatened that if D.X.C. “persisted in 
14  [his] asylum claim, they would have to separate” him from his son, that the separation 
15  could last “for at least two years[,]” and that his son would be put up for adoption.  (ECF 
16  No. 430 at 79.)  Given these facts, the Court finds D.X.C.’s decision to withdraw his 
17  credible fear claim was involuntary and his subsequent removal was unlawful.

10  O.U.R.M. – Defendants contend O.U.R.M. was lawfully removed pursuant to an 
11  expedited removal order.  (Defs.’ Supp. Br. at 2.)  They assert he received a negative 
12  credible fear finding, and that he did not pursue review by an IJ.  (Id.)  Notably, Defendants 
13  fail to submit any evidence reflecting that O.U.R.M. had a credible fear interview, or the 
14  results of that interview, such as a Form I-869, Record of Negative Credible Fear Finding

16  evidence is important and ought to exist.  “If an alien is found not to have a credible fear 
17  of persecution of torture, the asylum officer shall provide the alien with a written notice of 
18  decision and inquire whether the alien wishes to have an immigration judge review the 
19  negative decision, using Form I-869[.]”  Id. § 208.30(g)(1).  Further, if the alien refuses to 
20  indicate whether he or she desires such review, “the alien … shall be considered [to have 
21  made] a request for review.”  Id.

25  separated from his son, during which time O.U.R.M. did not know his son’s whereabouts 
26  nor have an opportunity to speak with him.  (ECF No. 430 at 130.)  O.U.R.M. states,
